Marguerite (de France) de Lanoy was a Huguenot emigrant (1540-1790).

Biography

Marguerite (de France) de Lanoy has French origins.

Little is known of French Huguenot "Marguerite de France," (she was not of French royalty, this added "surname" indicated her French and noble origins), except that she was born around 1640-1650, most-likely in Calais, Pas-de-Calais, France. As a French Protestant, she was subject to increasing religious harassment and persecution under King Louis XIV in the later part of the 17th Century.

In around 1667, at about 17 years old, Marguerite married Nicolas de Lanoy, b: 1640, also from the Pas-de-Calais province in the north of France. He was most-likely part of the Huguenot congregation in the town of Guînes, near Calais. The couple married in Pas-de-Calais, France. They were of the French "petite noblesse" or rural landed-gentry, a number of whom converted to the "reformed religion" preached by Jean Calvin between 1550 and 1650.

Marguerite and Nicolas had 5 children, all born in Europe:[1]

Francois de Lanoy, b: ca. 1670 in France

Marie de Lanoy, b. ca. 1675, d. b 1 Oct 1704 in Cape Colony

Nicolas de Lanoy, b. ca. 1678 in France

Mathieu de Lanoy, b. ca. 1679 in France or Holland

Suzanne de Lanoy, b. ca. 1680 in France or Holland

The family emigrated, doubtlessly via the Protestant-ruled Netherlands / Holland, to the Dutch Cape Colony in South Africa on December 31, 1687, with a group of Huguenot colonists, among the first in the region.[2][3]

Nicolas de Lanoy apparently died shortly after their arrival in the Cape Colony, around 1688. His widow and her 2 oldest boys received local public assistance as of 1690. Her daughter, Marie de Lanoy, married a fellow-French Huguenot refugee, Ary Lecremant (aka Arij Lekkerwijn) in 1692 at 17 years old. At his death in 1697, she remarried to Hans Heinrich Hatting on 19 January 1698.[4]

Marguerite (de France) de Lanoy died at Groot Drakenstein in the Dutch Cape Colony, South Africa, at 58 years old. As she was born around/before 1650, this would have been around 1705.

Marguerite de France on Geni.com

Huguenots embarqués pour l'Afrique du Sud. States the family was from "Wynen, Flandres". This is not a village name; it means "wines" in Flemish, indicating their area produced wine. Similarly, Marguerite's daughter's 1st husband's French surname was listed as "Decrement," meaning "Sweet-Wine;" its Dutch translation was "Lekkerwijn". ["Lecrevent" is a mis-spelling of Lecrement].

Wells & Scott Genealogy (USA & South Africa) Marie de Lanoy Probably lists her parents' birth years as a bit too early; other sources state they were born closer to 1650.
